comments:
This course presents an analysis of overall private wealth management. This includes planning for disposition of closely-held business interests; the impact of income taxes and other transfer costs on business interests and other assets; integration of life insurance, disability insurance, medical benefits, and long-term care insurance in the financial plan; planning for concentrated asset (e.g. common stock) positions, diversification techniques, and asset allocation strategies; distribution of retirement assets; lifetime giving and estate planning; and analysis of current developments in the creation, conservation, and distribution of estates. Attention also is given to various executive compensation techniques (including restricted stock and stock options) and planning for various employee benefits. The course also covers sophisticated charitable giving techniques and methods for financing education expenses. Reading consists of textbooks, case studies, and bulk pack articles.
Students found the course to be “very useful and informative.” The course “provides a good overview of wealth management.” The “financial planning methods, different insurance products, and taxation practices” learned were “highly useful for almost all students, especially those students considering a career in wealth management.”
Professor Hallman “cares about students learning” but his “lack of technical know-how impedes” the lectures, as he was unable to use a projector and show slides while lecturing for 1.5 hours. Professor Hallman is also not available via email but is “very generous with his time outside of class” as well as extremely knowledgeable about the material. “Professor Hallman had office hours each week and routinely was willing to stay longer than the allotted time amount to answer students’ questions.”
Students would recommend this course to anyone.
